verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: Major sections in Numbers begin with the LORD's instructions to Moses. This establishes divine authority and continuity with prior revelation, hinting at the need for an appointed mediator who delivers God's law.

verses.text: "Command the Israelites to send out from the camp everyone who has a skin disease, or a discharge, and whoever is made unclean by contact with the dead.
verses.comment: Physical impurity leads to separation from the assembly. This anticipates the need for spiritual cleansing, fulfilled in Christ’s healing ministry (cf. Matt. 8:2-3).

verses.text: Send them away, both male and female. You must send them outside the camp so that they do not defile the camp, where I dwell among them."
verses.comment: God’s presence demands purity in His people. The concept of defilement stresses the need for sanctification, later prominently taught in Christian tradition (cf. Heb. 12:14).

verses.text: The Israelites did so, sending them outside the camp. As the LORD had spoken to Moses, so the Israelites did.
verses.comment: Obedience is foundational for maintaining communion with God. Notice the role of Moses in mediating and transmitting God's instructions, prefiguring the continuity of spiritual authority.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses:
verses.comment: A new section begins, again emphasizing the importance of prophecy and revelation through an appointed leader.

verses.text: "Speak to the Israelites: When a man or woman commits any sin against another, betraying the LORD’s trust by doing wrong, that person is guilty.
verses.comment: All sin is ultimately against God, even when committed against another. This principle echoes Psalm 51:4, and recalls Jesus’ teaching that reconciliation with others is essential (Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: They must confess the sin they have committed, make full restitution for their wrong, add a fifth to it, and give it to the person they have wronged.
verses.comment: Confession, restitution, and penance are required for reconciliation. This foreshadows the practice of confession and acts of satisfaction in later Christian tradition (see James 5:16).

verses.text: But if the person has no close relative to whom restitution can be made, the restitution belongs to the LORD and must be given to the priest, along with the ram of atonement, which will make atonement for the guilty person.
verses.comment: When no relative exists, the priest stands as mediator for both restitution and atonement, a role mirrored in later spiritual authority and sacramental practice in the New Covenant (cf. John 20:23).

verses.text: Any sacred contribution that the Israelites bring to the priest belongs to him.
verses.comment: Gifts and offerings given for holy purposes are directed to the priesthood, highlighting support of ordained ministry and the principle of offering firstfruits.

verses.text: Each person’s holy gifts remain his own; what he gives to the priest belongs to the priest."
verses.comment: Clarifies the ownership and distribution of offerings. The priesthood’s share sustains those set apart for service—an enduring principle in Christian worship communities.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses:
verses.comment: Another direct revelation marks the introduction of a new legal case—here, the law concerning marital fidelity and suspicion.

verses.text: "Speak to the Israelites and say: If any man’s wife goes astray and is unfaithful to him,
verses.comment: Introduces the instruction about suspected adultery, which is treated seriously because it disrupts the covenant community—this protects marriage’s sacredness.

verses.text: and a man has sexual relations with her secretly and she is defiled though there is no witness against her and she was not caught in the act,
verses.comment: The situation involves a secret crime where witnesses are absent. It demonstrates the seriousness of hidden sin and the need for truth to be revealed before God.

verses.text: and if a spirit of jealousy comes over a husband and he becomes suspicious of his wife, though she has not defiled herself,
verses.comment: Raises the question of suspicion and jealousy, internal states that are themselves of spiritual concern (cf. Matt. 5:28).

verses.text: then the man must bring his wife to the priest. He must also bring an offering for her: one-tenth of an ephah of barley flour; he must not pour oil or place frankincense on it, for it is a grain offering of jealousy, a reminder offering to bring guilt to light.
verses.comment: Appeal to the priest as mediator shows the communal and sacramental dimension to resolving deep interpersonal conflicts—ceremonial offerings signify intent of uncovering the truth under God’s guidance.

verses.text: "The priest will bring her forward and make her stand before the LORD.
verses.comment: The accused stands before the LORD, not merely before human judges—invoking the divine tribunal anticipates the concept of judgment after death and necessity for intercessory mediation.

verses.text: He will take holy water in an earthen vessel, and from the floor of the Tabernacle the priest will take some dust and put it in the water.
verses.comment: Holy water and dust signify the seriousness of the ritual, foreshadowing sacraments that use material elements for spiritual purposes (cf. John 9:6-7).

verses.text: The priest will then have the woman stand before the LORD, uncover her head, and place in her hands the reminder offering—the grain offering for jealousy—while he holds the bitter water that brings a curse.
verses.comment: Uncovering the head symbolizes public exposure of the case. The bitter water is an outward sign of inward reality—pointing to visible signs representing invisible spiritual truths.

verses.text: The priest will make her take an oath, saying: ‘If no man has lain with you and you have not gone astray and defiled yourself while married, may this bitter water that brings a curse not harm you.
verses.comment: The oath invokes God’s justice and mercy, revealing the seriousness of the covenant in marriage and foreshadowing sacramental affirmations made before God (cf. Matt. 26:63).

verses.text: But if you have gone astray while married and defiled yourself, and a man has lain with you apart from your husband—"
verses.comment: Spells out the terms of the oath—as in many places, moral clarity is demanded and truth is essential before God.

verses.text: the priest shall put the woman under this oath of curse and say to her: ‘May the LORD make you cursed and an example among your people, if the LORD causes your thigh to waste away and your abdomen to swell.
verses.comment: Disease or physical sign will manifest as evidence of guilt. This public consequence underscores the principle that sin has real effects in the community and body—spiritual truth reflected in visible consequence.

verses.text: May this water that brings a curse enter your body, causing your abdomen to swell and your thigh to waste away.’ Then the woman must say, ‘Amen. Amen.’
verses.comment: The double ‘Amen’ signifies solemn agreement with the outcome, anticipating the liturgical use of ‘Amen’ as affirmation of faith.

verses.text: The priest will write these curses on a scroll, then wash them off into the bitter water.
verses.comment: Writing and washing off curses is highly symbolic—the act of physically transferring the written curse into water foreshadows spiritual cleansing and sacramental involvement of written Word and material elements.

verses.text: He will make the woman drink the bitter water that brings a curse and it will go into her to bring her pain.
verses.comment: The ritual uses a material element as a divine means of judgment. Such use of ‘signs’ and ‘means’ continues in Christian sacramental theology.

verses.text: Then the priest will take the grain offering for jealousy from the woman’s hand, lift it up before the LORD, and bring it to the altar.
verses.comment: Elevating the offering before the altar highlights the priest’s mediatorial role and the sacrificial nature of true repentance and reconciliation.

verses.text: The priest will take a handful of the grain offering as its memorial portion and burn it on the altar, and afterward he will have the woman drink the water.
verses.comment: The memorial portion establishes the principle of offering in remembrance—prefiguring the memorial aspect of Christian worship centered on offering for sin.

verses.text: If she has defiled herself and been unfaithful to her husband, the water that brings a curse will enter her, causing pain; her abdomen will swell and her thigh will waste away, and she will become a curse among her people.
verses.comment: Physical consequence and public disgrace follow guilt—a vivid illustration of sin’s real-world effects and the need for spiritually healing and restoration.

verses.text: But if the woman has not defiled herself and is clean, she will be unharmed and will be able to conceive children.
verses.comment: Vindication is accompanied by restored fruitfulness—God’s judgment brings both justice and life, a theme repeated throughout Scripture (cf. Job 42:12-17).

verses.text: This is the law concerning jealousy, when a woman goes astray and defiles herself while married,
verses.comment: This unique law provides a means of resolving marital suspicion, protecting the innocent as well as providing for public truth.

verses.text: or when a spirit of jealousy comes over a man and he becomes suspicious of his wife; he is to have the woman stand before the LORD, and the priest will carry out all these instructions.
verses.comment: Shows the priest’s explicit responsibility to judge rightly as God’s appointed mediator, preventing disorder through God-given rites and law.

verses.text: The husband will be clear of guilt, but the woman shall bear the consequences of her guilt.’”
verses.comment: Each bears responsibility for their own sin, and mediation by a designated spiritual authority is established. This foreshadows the need for sacramental confession, forgiveness, and restoration—important elements in Christian faith and practice.
